channel.title: BBC News - Science & Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Mystery 19th Century botanist tracked down following appeal
item.description: Pressed flowers and a poem found inside a centuries-old botany book sparked a quest to find the owner.

item.title: US wants giant radar in UK to track space objects
item.description: It comes amid growing concern about congestion, competition and even an arms race in space.

item.title: UK looks to extend ivory ban to hippos and other animals
item.description: Ministers say elephants are not the only animals at risk from hunters, as they launch consultation.

item.title: Climate change: Science failed to predict flood and heat intensity
item.description: Scientists want a super-computer powerful enough to accurately project the most damaging extremes.

item.title: Formula 1 boss Ross Brawn says hydrogen could be future fuel
item.description: Hydrogen-powered cars could be the future of Formula 1 according to Ross Brawn, the F1 managing director for motorsports.

item.title: National Food Strategy: Tax sugar and salt and prescribe veg, report says
item.description: Boris Johnson says he will consider the proposal, but finds the idea of extra taxes on people unattractive.

item.title: Climate change: 'No more excuses' at COP26 climate summit - poor nations
item.description: More than 100 developing countries set out key demands ahead of the climate summit in Glasgow.

item.title: Blue Origin: Teenager to fly into space with Jeff Bezos
item.description: Oliver Daemen, 18, will become the youngest person to fly to space with the Blue Origin venture.

item.title: Nasa set for attempt to fix Hubble's trouble
item.description: A possible cause is identified for the Hubble telescope's worst glitch in years.

item.title: Climate change: Amazon regions emit more carbon than they absorb
item.description: Rising heat and deforestation cause eastern parts of the Amazon to become carbon sources, not sinks.

item.title: Carry on flying, says government green plan
item.description: The policy has been ridiculed by environmentalists who say the government is putting too much faith in innovation.

item.title: EU unveils sweeping climate change plan
item.description: It proposes taxing jet fuel and effectively banning the sale of petrol cars within 20 years.

item.title: Climate crisis rallies young people
item.description: Thousands of young people are joining a mission to help solve the environmental crisis facing their generation.

item.title: Prince Charles' warning over survival of small farms
item.description: If they go out of business it will "rip the heart out of the British countryside", he says.

item.title: Benjamin Jesty: The unsung hero of vaccination
item.description: Edward Jenner is credited with inventing the vaccine but his method was pioneered by a Dorset farmer.

item.title: Giant goldfish problem in US lake prompts warning to pet owners
item.description: Goldfish released into the wild can grow much bigger and cause major disruption to ecosystems.

item.title: Fire lookouts: The US Forest Service lookouts watching for fires
item.description: In remote towers, US Forest Service lookouts act as an early warning system for forest fires.

item.title: Climate change: Technology boosts efforts to curb tree loss in Amazon
item.description: Smartphones and satellite data help indigenous people in the Peruvian Amazon to limit deforestation.

item.title: US heatwave: Could US and Canada see the worst wildfires yet?
item.description: The annual fire season has barely started - and there are claims that 2021 might be the worst year yet.

item.title: Climate change: US-Canada heatwave 'virtually impossible' without warming
item.description: Without global warming, the searing heat seen in the western US and Canada "just doesn't occur," say scientists.

item.title: Record June temperatures point to more 'extraordinary' extremes
item.description: North America experienced its warmest June on record and experts say the figures are frightening.

item.title: Florida breaks manatee death record in first six months of 2021
item.description: Wildlife authorities say the unprecedented number of deaths was primarily caused by starvation.

item.title: Why North America's killer heat scares me
item.description: It's not the new record temperatures that concern the BBC's Roger Harrabin - it's the way they were smashed.

item.title: Climate change: Planting extra trees will boost rainfall across Europe
item.description: Converting agricultural land to forestry would boost summer rains by 7.6% on average, a study finds.

item.title: Virgin Galactic: Richard Branson's long, winding path to space
item.description: The BBC tracks the long, winding road to Sir Richard Branson's flight to the edge of space.

item.title: Virgin Galactic: Sir Richard Branson rockets to the edge of space
item.description: The UK businessman realises a lifetime's ambition by riding a rocket plane high into the sky.

item.title: Blue Origin flight: Wally Funk, 82, to join Jeff Bezos space flight
item.description: The historic journey will see her become the oldest person to ever fly to space.

item.title: Virgin Galactic's Beth Moses: 'No camera can capture the magic'
item.description: Virgin Galactic's chief astronaut instructor, Beth Moses, describes the experience of spaceflight.

item.title: Covid origins: Scientists weigh up evidence over virus's origins
item.description: Researchers aim to "set the record straight" on how the virus transferred from bats into humans.

item.title: Appeal to identify 'La Botaniste' who slipped from history
item.description: Who was the mysterious Isabella Allen and what was her contribution to 19th Century botanical science?

item.title: Climate change: How can you make your home eco-friendly?
item.description: There are many ways to reduce a property's environmental impact, says the Energy Saving Trust.

item.title: Astronomy Photographer of the Year 2021: Shortlist revealed
item.description: The competition has received more than 4,500 entries from people in 75 countries.
